writingPrompt.content:
After you took the self-regulated learning survey, you received feedback about your strengths and weaknesses as a learner, as well as suggestions for becoming a more effective and efficient learner. Now, in order to receive feedback on your writing, please use the feedback from your self-regulated learning survey to do your best writing in a brief essay (about 500 words) that addresses the following questions:
  • What do your self-regulated learning survey results and the feedback tell you about your strengths and weaknesses as a college student? Use results from the survey and the feedback to provide an overview, and to support your analysis.
  • Which suggestions from the feedback are you committed to using this term? Why those?

content.startTips:
Your writing will be assessed according to the following criteria:
  • Evidence of Logical Reasoning
  • Organization
  • Paragraphs Focus on a Main Idea
  • Connecting Ideas
  • Conventions

supplementTable.content: The discussion of the survey and feedback is superficial and/or simplistic. Choices of suggestions to which to commit are vague, if present at all. The rationale for the choices is opaque; little evidence of logical reasoning.

The essay uses evidence from survey results and feedback to summarize student's strengths and weaknesses in terms of selfregulated learning. The overview is a bit thin; lacks detail. Choices of suggestions to which to commit are clearly described, but may not be reasonably connected to the strengths and weaknesses discussed in the overview.

The essay uses relevant survey results, feedback, and perhaps life experiences to provide a detailed overview of the studentâ€™s strengths and weaknesses in terms of selfregulated learning. The overview of the feedback logically leads to choices of suggestions to which to commit. The rationale for choices of suggestions is clear and reasonable.

supplementTable.content: There structure and order of the essay is unclear, making the analysis difficult to follow. The introduction and/or conclusion is/are unclear, insufficient, or irrelevant. Paragraphs abruptly transition from one to the next.

The essay has a general structure and order, but the arguments are not always easy to follow. The essay begins with an introduction that provides a vague but relevant gist of the essay The essay ends with a general summation of main points. Might include new or irrelevant ideas, or exclude one or more main points. Inconsistent use of transitions.

The essay is well-organized, with an order and structure that present the analysis in a clear, logical manner. The introduction provides a clear road map for the essay. The conclusion provides a clear and succinct summary of the main points of the essay. The writer uses rhetorically appropriate transitions to link one paragraph to the next and help readers follow the discussion.

supplementTable.content: Too few linking words and phrases mean that the connections between ideas in sentences within a paragraph are unclear.

The ideas or information in each sentence within a paragraph are generally linked together, if only loosely. Additional or better choices of linking words and phrases would clarify the connections b/w ideas within the paragraph.

Within paragraphs, the individual sentences are linked together seamlessly in a way that allows the reader to see the relationship between the ideas or information in one sentence and those in another sentence. The writing contains adverbs (e.g., similarly, also, therefore, etc.), relative pronouns (e.g., who, that, which), and conjunctions (e.g., and, or, while, whereas) that explicitly link sentences and ideas together.
